content: The "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" limits the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994 limits building height based on street width and restricts the size and height of roof structures not used for human occupancy. The District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994 allows structures not used for human occupancy to be built taller than the prescribed limit if approved by the Mayor, with the condition that they must be fireproof and set back from the building's walls. The Mayor can waive this requirement if it is found to be overly restrictive or impractical. The District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994 allows for waivers of building height restrictions if it does not interfere with the Act's purpose or affect neighboring buildings' light and air exposure. The Act defines "exterior or bounding wall" and "roof" for clarification. Penalties for violations have been increased. The District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994 has increased penalties for violations, with fines now ranging up to $10,000 per day for non-compliance and up to $100,000 for violating an injunction. The National Capital Planning Commission's authority to enforce building height limitations has been increased. The National Capital Planning Commission's authority to enforce building height limitations has been expanded to require approval for roof structures exceeding general limitations. This includes involving the Mayor of the District of Columbia and the National Capital Planning Commission in the approval process. The National Capital Planning Commission's authority has been expanded to include approval of roof structures exceeding building height limitations in the District of Columbia. The amendments made by this Act will apply to buildings and structures in the District of Columbia for which building permits are issued on or after March 23, 1994.
